A press release by Election Commission reads, "ECI reviews Inter-State border preparedness; Directs strict vigil to ensure peaceful, inducement-free Bihar Assembly Elections 2025." https://t.co/AraH1YCY4b

Bihar Assembly Elections 2025

The Election Commission of India (ECI) has undertaken a comprehensive review of the preparedness along the inter-state borders in view of the forthcoming Bihar Assembly Elections 2025.

During the review, the Commission emphasized the importance of maintaining strict vigilance at all inter-state check-posts, transit routes, and vulnerable border locations to prevent the movement of illegal cash, liquor, drugs, or any other inducements that could influence the integrity of the electoral process.

The Commission has directed all concerned authorities to work in close coordination with state police, central armed forces, and enforcement agencies to ensure robust security arrangements. Special instructions have been issued to intensify surveillance, strengthen intelligence-sharing mechanisms, and deploy adequate personnel along sensitive border areas.

The ECI reiterated its commitment to conduct peaceful, fair, and inducement-free elections in Bihar. It assured the public that every possible measure will be taken to guarantee a secure environment for voters to exercise their democratic right without fear, influence, or unlawful interference.

Bihar assembly elections 2025.  New update. 12000 voters covered now.

1. Bihar - 243 seats.
2. Others- 8 seats.
3. INDI- 95 seats.
4. NDA- 130 seats.
5. Balance 10 seats under analysis or CantSays.
6.  Towards the last end mile of this election, it is becoming completely candidate specific.  Voters are found becoming completely ruthless rejecting non performers or those they perceive as not impactful.  Bihar has had history of changing MLAs. In that way I appreciate the average Bihari voter. They like to experiment and try new MLAs.
7. Nearly half of the seats, the voters seem to be throwing out existing MLAs (In my excel)
8. NDA range could be 120 to 150.
9. INDI- range could be 85 to 110. 
10. 12000 voters heard in Bihar.
11. As always there is no guarantee to any poll or any pollster  in India. No pollster can gauge last minute vote shifts on voting day.  We need to note that there is phenomenal badlav desire, badlav noises on the ground in Bihar.

Top 10 swing / battleground assembly seats in Bihar to watch in the 2025 election, 

There is a close fight between the NDA and the INDIA/Mahagathbandhan, and several high-profile constituencies — where leaders, narrow past margins, or new entrants matter — can decide the balance. 

Raghopur (Vaishali) — Tejashwi Yadav’s seat and a high-profile contest; symbolic and electorally important if the RJD leader faces a strong challenge. 

Mahua — Returning contestants and factional fights (including local heavyweights) make this a close three-way battle. 

Harnaut — Considered Nitish Kumar / JD(U) terrain; any slip here signals wider anti-incumbency for JD(U). 

Sheohar — Three-cornered contests and local swings make it unpredictable and useful as a barometer. 

Hathua — Lalu/Yadav family connections and local loyalties mean close margins; important for MGB (Mahagathbandhan) pride. 

Raghunathpur (Siwan area) — Recent reports flagged it as a seat where RJD influence is being challenged — watch for new entrants/independents. 

Biharsharif — Identified in reporting as a battleground with potential for surprise swings between alliances. 

Narkatiaganj — One of the constituencies listed where alliance coordination and seat sharing are contentious; close fights likely. 

Valmiki Nagar (West Champaran) — High local competition and seat allocation dynamics inside the NDA make this one to watch. 

Sikta / Sikta-area seats — Reported as constituencies with tight margins last time and potential INDIA-bloc internal contestation; could be decisive locally. 

Why these matter

They are either seats with top leaders, very small margins in the previous election, or complex multi-party contests where vote-splitting could change the outcome. 

Several are listed in recent press roundups of “seats to watch” and in coverage of where alliance seat-sharing or new parties (e.g., JSP, LJP(RV)) could alter results.

@IndianTechGuide The remark came during his campaign for the 2025 Bihar Legislative Assembly election, in a rally in Muzaffarpur, Bihar.  

He was criticizing the policies of the ruling Narendra Modi-led government (and its allies) for what he claimed was an over-reliance on products imported from China and insufficient local manufacturing.  

He used “Made in Bihar” as a slogan to emphasise what he claims should be a stronger focus on manufacturing, local jobs, especially in Bihar. He said:
“Mobiles, shirts, pants, all these should be made in Bihar and the youth of Bihar should get employment in those factories. We want such a Bihar.”

This election is to save Bihar from jungle raj (lawlessness). We have witnessed jungle raj before, Begusarai was once an industrial district, but one by one, all industries on this land disappeared. Bihar’s soil was soaked in blood because of heinous crimes. Industries of crime,  murder, ransom, extortion, and abduction, began to flourish. For 15 years, Lalu and Rabri devastated the land of Bihar. Now, after 20 years, that same jungle raj is returning in the form of Tejashwi and Rahul’s alliance. Bihar Election 2025: प्रशांत किशोर का विवादित बयान! 🗳️

कटिहार में प्रचार के दौरान प्रशांत किशोर ने सीमांचल के मुस्लिम मतदाताओं से कहा —

भाजपा से नहीं, अल्लाह से डरिए… लालटेन में तेल डालते रहेंगे तो लालूजी के घर में रोशनी होगी, आपके बच्चों के जीवन में नहीं।

इस बयान ने बिहार की सियासत में नई बहस छेड़ दी है 🔥

👉 धर्म और डर की राजनीति करने वाले बयान पर जनता का सवाल साफ है —
क्या बिहार अब फिर उसी तुष्टिकरण की राह पर लौटेगा,
या NDA के विकास और शांति के रास्ते को चुनेगा? 🇮🇳

गायघाट में टिकट बंटवारे ने सियासी हलचल मचा दी है। दिनेश सिंह की बेटी को टिकट मिलने से नाराज चार बार के विधायक महेश्वर राय और बेटे प्रभात किरण ने आरजेडी का दामन थाम लिया है।

#Bihar: A viral CCTV video from a restaurant in Barsoi, Katihar district on 26th October 2025, shows police officers confronting a man dining with his sister, allegedly demanding her identity in a derogatory manner amid election vigilance checks.

The clip, shared widely on X, has triggered outrage over privacy violations and possible breaches of the Model Code of Conduct during the ongoing Bihar Assembly elections.
Authorities have launched an internal probe, as public calls grow for accountability and the use of body cameras to ensure transparency in policing.

In Bihar election @PrashantKishor has stolen the show on all media platforms but on ground zero the Bihar assembly election-2025 is turning out to be @BJP4India versus @RJDforIndia fight. 

The local public discourse is about @yadavtejashwi. Non-yadav OBC and extremely backward Hindus, particularly, young voters are calculating advantages and disadvantages of bringing in change after two decades. 
@BJP4India led coalition is extremely aware of it. 
Their counter is robust, too. 
The Bjp leaders including @narendramodi and @AmitShah are working hard to revive memories of Jungle Raj. 
The senior voters are definitely conscious of ‘insecurity’ in the society in pre-Nitish era. 
But, young voters are unaware of what ‘jungle raj’ actually mean. 
They are listening to new stories, too. 
The anti-NDA forces are talking vigorously about Bhrashtachar Raj. 
In every constituency sitting MLAs are facing challenges. 
In a clever move @yadavtejashwi has cut tickets of more than 30 sitting MLAs. 
People are quite aware of health related issue of @NitishKumar but it’s not creating negativity against him.
‘Kaam nahi hue’ is the issue against his government. 
However, after debating poll scenarios many Bihari voters murmur to me before parting  ‘vote  to Jaat per hi padega.’
I asked one fisherman: But, why?
Response came: Beti aur vote jaati main hi dena chahiye!
(while voting and in fixing marriages caste consideration is necessary) 
One well-informed voter belonging to Mallah community tells 
me ‘NDA is Mahagathbandhan of castes!’ 
In Bihar, the situation has developed where the BJP is trying to absorb and retain dissent votes of @Jduonline which can otherwise shift to @RJDforIndia or @PrashantKishor in this election. 
All said and done this is one more election where @BJP4India is banking heavily on women voters and the opposition wants youth to rebel against the rulers. 
Nobody ever believed Biharis can be taken for granted. 
When we visit villages in Bihar we understand why.

Bihar Elections and bye-elections 2025: Prohibition of display of Election Matter in Silence Period and Exit Poll

▪️The Election Commission of India (ECI) announced the schedule for the General Election to Legislative Assembly of Bihar and bye-elections on October 6, 2025

▪️Polling in the Bihar elections will be held in two phases on November 6, 2025 and November 11, 2025 respectively

▪️Section 126 (1)(b) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, prohibits displaying any election matter by means, inter alia, of television or similar apparatus, in any polling area during the period of forty-eight hours (silence period) ending with the hour fixed for the conclusion of the poll for any election in that polling area

Bihar Elections and bye-elections 2025: Assured Minimum Facilities and Voter Assistance to be provided at All Polling Stations

The Election Commission of India (ECI) announced the schedule for the General Election to Legislative Assembly of Bihar and bye-elections in 8ACs on October 6, 2025.

ECI has issued directions to the Chief Electoral Officers (CEOs) of the States/UTs to ensure that every Polling Station is equipped with Assured Minimum Facilities (AMFs) and voter assistance during poll-day.

AMF include drinking water, waiting shed, toilet with water facility, adequate lighting, a ramp of proper gradient for PwD electors, a standard voting compartment, and proper signage.

To strengthen voter awareness, four uniform and standardized Voter Facilitation Posters (VFP) shall be prominently displayed at all polling stations containing the Polling Station Details, List of Candidates, Do’s and Don’ts, list of Approved Identification Documents and the voting process.

Murder & Intimidation by Mohammad Shahabuddin:   

His Son is fighting on RJD ticket in 2025 Bihar election.

Mohammad Shahabuddin, RJD MP from Siwan, rose as a feared “bahubali” overseeing kidnapping, extortion, and murders.  

 In March 1999, CPI-ML worker Chhote Lal Gupta was abducted and disappeared the court later sentenced Shahabuddin to life for kidnapping presumed murder. 

In 1997, he was accused of orchestrating the mass shooting at a student meeting killing Chandrashekhar Prasad and others.   

Journalists exposing him, like Rajdev Ranjan who reported on Shahabuddin’s activities, were later murdered.

Bihar assembly elections 2025.  New update. 11000 voters crossed.

1. Bihar - 243 seats.
2. Others- 6 seats.
3. INDI- 85 seats.
4. NDA- 119 seats and 3 short of majority.
5. Balance 33 seats under analysis. 
6. It is not an easy election many think it is. There is state wide fatigue on Nitish among young to middle aged, they want change. However among the elderly Nitish is popular due to relief measures. Women continue to support Nitish and they will in the end save his govt from falling. 
6. JanSuraaj is cutting lot of Upper caste middle class votes which go to NDA however they are also cutting male youth votes which go to Tejaswi.  
7.  Despite relief measures, the citizens are looking very hard at candidates nominated. MLA work is being evaluated closely and voting will depend on that.

Bihar Elections and bye-elections 2025: Citizens empowered to report poll- violations using C-Vigil App on ECINet

💠The Election Commission of India has announced the schedule for the General Election to the Legislative Assembly of Bihar, 2025 and the bye-elections for 8ACs. The Commission has directed to the State/UT governments to ensure strict compliance with the instructions to enforce the Model Code of Conduct (MCC).

💠824 Flying squads have been deployed across Bihar to ensure that the complaints are attended to within 100 minutes.

💠Citizens/political parties can also report MCC violations using the C-Vigil App on ECINET.

💠As on October 21, 2025, 650 complaints have been lodged using the C-Vigil App in the Bihar elections and the bye-elections bound States/UT. Of these, 649 have been disposed of and 612 complaints i.e., 94% of the complaints were resolved within 100 minutes.

Bihar assembly election 2025.  New Update. NDA marching to a win. 10502 voters heard. NDA seems to have 55% plus of the women vote and thus the game changer

1. Bihar - 243 seats. 
2. Others- 5 seats.
3. INDI- 79 seats. 
4. NDA- 108 seats. 
5. Balance 51 seats under analysis.
6. NDA 15 seats short of majority and marching towards a win.
7. I hope I am able to complete balance analysis in next few days. 
8. Jan Suraaj seems to be losing steam of late, not seeing much mention.  Thus looks like JS will be playing spoiler. 
9. Nitish Kumar is surely one of the shrewd politicians in India.  His caste is less than 5% in Bihar and he is CM for 20 years that demolishes the caste voting in some sense. Note Laloo Yadav is also very shrewd and I believe his son Tejaswi is not half as shrewd as Laloo is. Laloo Yadav has superb idea of caste combinations and often nominates superb candidates to torment the opposition.  However overall INDI candidate selection seems poor this time.  Congress should have changed many of their MLAs but fails to do so. Their state head Rajesh Ram may end up losing in Kutumba. 
10. The last 15-20 days of this election is now totally on candidates in marginal seats, their appeal in their seats, the caste voting.  Surprisingly not seeing big number of rebels, the NDA has been extremely disciplined in wanting to win this election without rebels.

Bihar Election, 2025: Pre-certification of print-ads by Media Certification and Monitoring Committee (MCMC) on Pre-poll and Poll Day 

➡️ In order to ensure a fair campaign environment, no Political Party, candidate, organization or person shall publish any advertisement in the print media on the poll day and one day prior to the poll day, unless the contents are pre-certified by the MCMC at the State/District level

➡️ For #Bihar, the restricted days are November 5 & 6, 2025 (for Phase-I) and November 10 & 11, 2025 (for Phase-II)

➡️ Applicants seeking pre-certification for political advertisements in print media must apply to the MCMC not later than two days prior to the proposed date of publication of the advertisement

📌RLM leans toward OBCs like Koeri

🗳️ Bihar Assembly Elections 2025: The Race Heats Up! 🗳️

Bihar is set for a high-stakes election with major parties announcing their candidates for all 243 seats. Here’s the latest on who’s fighting for your vote:

🔥 NDA Alliance:

BJP has released a full list of 101 candidates, including top leaders like Samrat Choudhary (Tarapur), Vijay Sinha (Lakhisarai), and folk singer Maithili Thakur (Alinagar). They re-nominated 85 sitting MLAs, reinforcing experience.

JD(U) also contests 101 seats with a mix of veterans led by Chief Minister Nitish Kumar and fresh faces focused on caste and regional balance.

Allies LJP (Ram Vilas), HAM, and RLM have finalized their candidates, completing the NDA’s strong lineup.

⚔️ INDIA Bloc:

RJD’s star candidate is Tejashwi Yadav (Raghopur), with over 30 candidates announced so far.

Congress has cleared about 50 candidates, focusing on key regions like Patna and Seemanchal.

The Left parties, led by CPI(ML)-Liberation, are contesting 18 seats with grassroots leaders.

🌟 New Entrants:

Jan Suraaj, led by Prashant Kishor, is contesting over 100 seats with professionals and activists aiming to bring a fresh voice to Bihar politics.

📅 Mark your calendars! Voting is scheduled for November 6 and 11, and results will be declared on November 14.

💡 Stay informed, know your candidates, and make your vote count in shaping Bihar’s future.

ECI issues directions to Enforcement Agencies to prevent use of money power in upcoming Bihar elections

💠The Election Commission of India announced the schedule for the General Election to Legislative Assembly of Bihar and the bye-elections in 8 ACs on October 6, 2025.

💠Expenditure Observers have already been deployed to monitor the election expenses incurred by the Candidates and have reached their respective Constituencies on the day of the notification of elections. During the visit they will meet all the teams engaged in expenditure monitoring.

💠Flying Squads, Surveillance Teams, Video Surveillance Teams will be vigilant round- the-clock to monitor any suspected instances of money power or other inducements being used to sway the voters.

📍Bihar Election 2025

बिहार की सियासत में चुनाव से पहले बड़ा उलटफेर —
प्रशांत किशोर की जन सुराज पार्टी को तगड़ा झटका!
राज्य के पूर्व मंत्री और जन सुराज के वरिष्ठ नेता मोनाजिर हसन साहब ने पार्टी से इस्तीफ़ा देकर ऑल इंडिया मजलिस-ए-इत्तेहादुल मुस्लिमीन (AIMIM) का दामन थाम लिया।

मोनाजिर हसन के AIMIM में शामिल होने से बिहार में मजलिस को मिला एक मज़बूत और अनुभवी चेहरा।
अब बिहार की जमीं पर बैरिस्टर असदुद्दीन ओवैसी साहब की क़ियादत में मजलिस और भी मज़बूती से आगे बढ़ेगी।

Bihar assembly elections 2025.  Out of 243 seats, Others- 5 seats, INDI- 71 seats and NDA- 96 seats, balance seats under analysis. 

An analysis of these 2025 elections with the previous election of 2020 and major issues, factors.

1. New entrant is Jan Suraaj and is stealing some male youth vote which went one sided to Tejaswi last time.
2. Jan Suraaj is also stealing upper caste votes of NDA from those who are fatigued with Nitish Kumar. These include all age groups.  This could lead to some seats of NDA flipping to INDI due to the JS taking away UC votes. Lot depends in the end on candidates. Note plenty voters are keeping a close watch on candidate announcement. Jan Suraaj is also stealing some Muslim vote.
3. Modi seems more popular than before. 
4. Nitish has reversed anti incumbency with his new relief measures.  But these will put pressures on finance of other states trying to emulate this.
5. As much as the male youth is attracted to Tejaswi, the women youth vote and women vote is staying intact with Nitish Kumar. In my view Nitish Kumar has done an outstanding job for Bihar women and more than any other state CM.  The women of Bihar are very wary of Jungle Raj and are thus staying intact with Nitish.
6. The elderly vote is consolidating to Nitish due to increase in Pensions.
7. Significant population of Bihar is disgusted with local corruption and is thinking change. Block level corruption is annoying local citizens. 
8. The paradox I face is that NDA has a 11% lead in vote share on INDI but the lead in seats is not that great, I think my NDA seat estimate may be very conservative.

➡️चुनावी मौसम शुरू होते ही पटना एयरपोर्ट बन गया है राजनीतिक दलों का नया ‘हेलीकॉप्टर हब’.  रोजाना 15 से 17 प्राइवेट हेलीकॉप्टर उड़ान भरेंगे.
➡️हेलीकॉप्टर से चुनावी सभा तक पहुंचने का खर्च प्रति घंटे 2–2.5 लाख रुपये, लेकिन अभियान के लिए कोई कसर नहीं छोड़ी जा रही.  
इस बार मुकाबला केवल धरती पर नहीं, हवा में भी होगा.

In June 2025, the Election Commission launched the Special Intensive Revision (SIR) in Bihar, claiming it was meant to identify and remove “infiltrators” — illegal foreign voters — from the electoral rolls. But three months later, when the SIR ended, it turned out that 4.7 million names were deleted without any explanation. The Commission hasn’t clarified how many illegal foreigners were found or why these names were removed. From Darbhanga to Munger, officials called the data “confidential.” Even on Aadhaar, the Commission’s stance remained unclear. In this episode of 'Janab Aise Kaise?', @shadabmoizee asks — did SIR bring transparency, or did it only deepen the mystery?

ECI issues directions for strict implementation of Model Code of Conduct for the Bihar elections

💠The Election Commission of India (ECI) announced the schedule for the General Election to Legislative Assembly of Bihar on October 6, 2025.

💠With this announcement, ECI has issued directions to Chief Secretary and Chief Electoral Officer of Bihar regarding immediate coming into force of the Model Code of Conduct (MCC) in the State. The MCC shall also be applicable to the Central Government so far as announcements/policy decisions for Bihar are concerned.
 
💠The privacy of citizens must be respected, with no demonstrations or picketing outside private residences. Land, buildings, or walls shall not be used for flags, banners, or posters without the owner’s consent.

💠A complaint monitoring system has been set up including a Call Centre number 1950 in which complaint can be lodged by any member of the public or political party, with the DEO/RO concerned. This system is now operational 24X7.

My piece on #battleforBihar 

The 2025 election in Bihar is not just a contest of votes; it is a referendum on whether the strength of experience and earned trust can outlast the allure of change and fresh promises. This election will reveal whether Nitish’s invisible advantage is enough to author the final chapter or whether Bihar is ready to turn the pages. The shadow of that iconic 2015 poster still lingers. But this time, the question behind “Phir Ek Baar, Nitish Kumar” is whether it signals a continuation or a dignified farewell to one of Bihar’s longest-serving leaders.

VIDEO | Patna: CPI (ML) General Secretary Dipankar Bhattacharya, reacting to announcement of Bihar Assembly Election 2025, said, “The way the election dates have been announced is quite surprising. Tomorrow, the Supreme Court is scheduled to hold the final hearing on the entire SIR matter. In a way, the issue of SIR and the voters’ list is sub judice. Earlier, the Supreme Court had also said that if there are major discrepancies, the election could even be cancelled. So, announcing the dates just a day before the hearing seems like bypassing the judicial process, which is not appropriate.”

(Full video available on PTI Videos –https://t.co/bIyFWTfmBd)

📢 Bihar Assembly Elections 2025 🗳️🗓️

​(As per Chief Election Commissioner Gyanesh Kumar):

📍​Total Electorate: 7.4 Crore 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦
📍​Male Voters: 3.9 Crore 🧑
📍​Female Voters: 3.5 Crore 👩
​The election will be held in two phases: ✌️
💬​Phase I Details: (प्रथम चरण)
​Nomination Period: October 10 to October 17 📝
​Polling Date: November 6 🔔
​Phase II Details: (द्वितीय चरण)
📍पहला चरण (🟡 पीले रंग से दर्शाए गए क्षेत्र) – 6 नवंबर
➡️बिहार के मध्य व दक्षिण के ज़िले 
📍दूसरा चरण (🟣 गुलाबी रंग से दर्शाए गए क्षेत्र) – 11 नवंबर
➡️ उत्तर, पश्चिम और पूर्वी बिहार के ज़िले 
​Nomination Period: October 13 to October 20 ✍️
​Polling Date: November 11 🎯
​Counting of Votes (Result Declaration): November 14 🎉🎊

PTI INFOGRAPHICS | Bihar Election 2025: Voting in two phases on Nov 6 and 11; counting of votes on Nov 14

The assembly elections in Bihar will be held in two phases, polling for which will be held on November 6 and 11, while the counting of votes will be done on November 14, Chief Election Commissioner Gyanesh Kumar announced on Monday.

The entire election process will be concluded by November 16.

"Bihar elections will be held in two phases on November 6 and 11. Counting of votes will be done on November 14," Kumar said at a press conference.

"It is mandatory to complete the counting of postal ballots before the last two rounds of counting of votes," he added.

🟥Bihar Election 2025: Voting in 2 phases (Nov 6, Nov 11). Counting on Nov 14.

🟥CEC: For the first time, one general observer for each of 243 constituencies; one police observer each for 38 districts. Over 7.4 crore voters in Bihar; 14 lakh first time voters. Mandatory to complete counting of postal ballots before last two rounds of counting of votes. Average 818 voters per polling booth, webcasting facilities at all polling booths. 

🟥All India Sarafa Association: Gold price surges Rs 9,700 to record Rs 1.3 lakh/10 g; silver hits lifetime high of Rs 1,57,400/kg in Delhi. 

🟥CM Rekha Gupta: Delhi govt to approach Supreme Court for allowing bursting of green crackers on Diwali. 

🟥Assam CM: Barring one, 7 others present with singer Zubeen Garg during his last moments in Singapore yet to respond to CID summons. Assam Police not required to go to Singapore for investigation into singer Zubeen Garg's death.

Bihar 2025 Election Freebies Threaten Fiscal Health and Capital Spending

Bihar election freebies: 2025 poll-related freebies worth ₹33,000 crore could worsen the state’s already high debt of ₹4.06 lakh crore.

Fiscal risk: High debt, low tax revenue, and unutilised funds may stall growth and reduce capital spending.

Debt-to-GSDP ratio: Bihar’s 2022–23 debt-to-GSDP ratio was 39.6%, higher than the median state, with above-average contingent liabilities (Niti Aayog, July 2025).

Revenue collection: Estimated tax revenue for 2025–26 is ₹59,520 crore against a total revenue of ₹2.6 lakh crore, below the median state.

Expenditure breakdown 2025–26: Total budget ₹2.94 lakh crore; ₹2.52 lakh crore (85.7%) for revenue expenditure; only ₹40,532 crore (13.7%) for capital outlay.

Comparative capital outlay: Uttar Pradesh: 21.8%; India Union budget 2025–26: 17.7% (PRS Research).

Freebies impact: Likely to reduce already low capital outlay further.

Unutilised funds: CAG report (July 2025) found ₹7,567.93 crore unspent across 20 major schemes in 2023–24.

NDA’s Key Welfare Schemes in Bihar (2025)

Social Security Pension Hike (June 21, 2025)

Pension for elderly, widows, and disabled increased from ₹400 → ₹1,100/month

Beneficiaries: 1.13 crore people

Free Electricity Scheme (July 17, 2025)

Free electricity up to 125 units/month per connection

Households covered: 1.67–1.89 crore

Enhanced Pension for Journalists (July 2025)

Pension raised from ₹6,000 → ₹15,000/month

Surviving spouses receive ₹10,000/month

Unemployment Allowance Scheme (September 18, 2025)

₹1,000/month for 2 years for unemployed graduates & Class 12 completers

Mukhyamantri Kalakar Pension Yojana (September 2025)

₹3,000/month for senior artistes in distress

Vikas Mitra Allowance (September 21, 2025)

One-time ₹25,000 allowance for tablets

Beneficiaries: 10,000+ community facilitators

Mukhyamantri Mahila Rojgar Yojana (September 26, 2025)

Initial grant of ₹10,000 per beneficiary via DBT

Potential additional support up to ₹2 lakh

🚨 BREAKING NEWS 🚨

CEC Gyanesh Kumar announces key measures to enhance transparency in Bihar Assembly Elections 2025

Patna, Bihar: Chief Election Commissioner Gyanesh Kumar said,

“Previously, when votes were counted, if there was a mismatch in Form 17C, which the presiding officer gives to polling agents, and in the EVM counting unit, all such VVPATs would be counted in full. Similarly, it will be compulsory that postal ballots be counted before the final two rounds of EVM counting. After the election is over, many people want to know how many voters there were, how many men voted, and how many women voted… now, gradually, the progressive implementation of ECI-NET is taking place. Therefore, you will all be able to see these digital index cards within a few days of the election’s conclusion.”

#BiharElections2025

🚨ECI is implementing new initiatives in Bihar Election 2025

➡️Mobile Deposit Facility at Polling Stations

➡️Clearer Voter Information Slip
Serial and part numbers displayed prominently for easier verification of voters.

➡️Many Important services on ECINet App including, Real-time Voter Turnout Updates.

➡️Polling Station Limit of 1,200 Voters.

➡️Booths by the candidates on poll day for issuing unofficial identity slips to electors can be set up just beyond 100 meters of any Polling Station.

➡️100% Webcasting at Polling Stations

➡️ECI revises guidelines to make EVM Ballot Papers more readable, EVMs to have colour photographs of candidates for the first time.

➡️Mandatory VVPAT Count for mismatches VVPAT slip counting in each and every case of mismatch between Form 17C and EVM data and wherever mock poll data was not erased erroneously.

➡️Penultimate (second last) round of EVM/VVPATs counting shall be taken up only after the counting of Postal Ballot Papers.

➡️Digital Index Cards & Reports

Election Commission officials held meetings with the Bihar police administration, heads of enforcement agencies, and nodal officers."

Election Commission of India reviews preparedness for Bihar Assembly Elections 2025

The Election Commission of India (ECI) today reviewed the preparedness for the upcoming Bihar Legislative Assembly Elections, 2025.

The Commission, led by Chief Election Commissioner Gyanesh Kumar, held a detailed meeting with the Chief Secretary, Director General of Police, and other senior officers to assess law and order, logistics, EVM readiness, and coordination between enforcement agencies.

Bihar SIR MESS 💥

𝐄𝐂'𝐬 𝐕𝐨𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐋𝐢𝐬𝐭 "𝐑𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧" – 𝟒.𝟔 𝐋𝐚𝐤𝐡 𝐏𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐭𝐨𝐦 𝐀𝐝𝐝𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 & 𝟏.𝟓 𝐋𝐚𝐤𝐡 𝐆𝐡𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐃𝐞𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐞𝐝!

The Election Commission's Bihar Special Intensive Revision (SIR) final report (Sept 30, 2025) was supposed to clarify the mess. Instead, it's a statistical nightmare.

🔻𝐀𝐝𝐝𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐌𝐢𝐬𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐜𝐡
By Sept 1, only 16.93 lakh applications received (16.56 lakh new voters + 36.5K claims from electors + 25 from parties). Yet, final added: 21.53 lakh electors. 𝙐𝙣𝙚𝙭𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙙 𝙨𝙪𝙧𝙥𝙡𝙪𝙨: 4.6 𝙡𝙖𝙠𝙝! Where did these extras come from? Form 6 opacity hides if they're new 18+ voters or reinstated ghosts from the 68.66 lakh deletions.

🔻𝐑𝐞𝐦𝐨𝐯𝐚𝐥𝐬 𝐑𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐥𝐞
Just 2.17 lakh objections by Sept 1 (2.17 lakh from electors + 119 from parties). Final removed: 3.66 lakh. 𝙎𝙪𝙧𝙥𝙡𝙪𝙨: 1.49 𝙡𝙖𝙠𝙝! No trace of these "objections" – pure procedural black hole.

With a Sept 1 "disposal" backlog of 1.7M+ cases (only 5-16% processed) and zero breakdowns, this process is audit-proof. 

Fairness? Mechanics? All buried in EC's Data Fog.

In Bihar’s 2025 voter list revision, 68.5 lakh names were deleted and only 21.53 lakh added a net loss of 47 lakh voters. Bihar’s adult population is 8.18 crore, yet the final list shows only 7.42 crore voters, leaving 76 lakh citizens missing.

The Election Commission itself stated that under Form-6, 16.93 lakh new applications were received, and no further claims were to be included in the final list. If only 16.93 lakh applied, how did the final roll show 21.53 lakh additions? Where did the extra 4.6 lakh voters come from without filing Form-6?

This is mass disenfranchisement under a compromised Election Commission.

@IndianTechGuide According to Hindustan Times, the Election Commission has published the final voter rolls for Bihar (as of September 30, 2025), and in that process about 47 lakh names have been removed (i.e. excluded) compared to the rolls before the Special Intensive Revision (SIR) began.  

Tribune India also reports that earlier the state had ~7.89 crore registered voters, and after the SIR exercise, that number dropped by nearly 47 lakh to ~7.42 crore.  

⚠ Caveats & wider picture

•The term removed here means that those names were excluded from the final rolls after scrutiny, claims & objections, verification, etc. It doesn’t necessarily imply all were wrongful removals.
•There are reports that the initial draft roll removed a larger number (e.g. ~65 lakh names) accounting for death, migration, duplicates, etc.  
•Some opposition parties and observers have claimed irregularities, alleging that eligible voters may have been wrongly excluded.
•Legal challenges are ongoing (including in the Supreme Court) around the SIR exercise, including fairness, due process, and whether proper identity/residence proofs were allowed.

@kanhaiyaku54000 @pbhushan1 The Election Commission of India deleted ~65 lakh voters from Bihar's draft rolls in the 2025 SIR for reasons like duplicates, deceased, or migration. Muslim population in Bihar is ~17% per 2011 census, likely similar for voters. Analyses vary: some suggest higher deletions in Muslim-majority areas, others find no disproportionate impact or even higher Hindu deletions. The post's 24% figure is from unofficial name-based classification, not verified by ECI. Official data doesn't break down by community.

Dharmendra Pradhan Gets Crucial Assignment as BJP’s Bihar Election In-Charge

Union Education Minister @dpradhanbjp has been appointed the BJP's election in-charge for the upcoming Bihar Assembly polls, expected to be announced in October 2025. 

The decision was formally conveyed by BJP national president JP Nadda, underscoring the party’s high-stakes strategy to reclaim the politically pivotal state.

Dharmendra Pradhan will be assisted by Union Water Resources Minister CR Patil and Uttar Pradesh Deputy CM Keshav Prasad Maurya as co-in-charges.

Dharmendra Pradhan’s credentials were cemented with his successful handling of the 2024 Haryana Assembly elections, where the BJP defied anti-incumbency and opposition alliances to secure a historic third consecutive term, winning 48 of 90 seats. His meticulous focus on grassroots mobilisation and OBC outreach was widely credited for the turnaround.

Bihar election 2025
📢📢बिहार चुनाव में जातियों की राजनीति सिर चढ़कर बोलती है। बड़े-बड़े नेताओं के जुलूस और जातीय समीकरण ऐसे, जैसे इलैक्शन की गाड़ी खींचने के लिए बुलंदी और बिरादरी दोनों जरूरी। रैली प्लेटफॉर्म से वादे उछाले जाते हैं—सड़कें, हॉस्पिटल, करोड़ों नौकरियां, मुफ्त स्कीम—लेकिन मूल सवाल यह है कि जनता को कितना हकीकत नजर आता है?
#️⃣उदाहरण के तौर पर, पिछले चुनावों में “पीढ़ी दर पीढ़ी शिक्षा” और “बिजली-सड़क-पानी” के वादे लुभावने थे, लेकिन आज भी छात्रों को स्कूल की दीवारें ध्वस्त होती दिखती हैं, सरकारी प्राइमरी स्कूलों में शिक्षकों की कमी खलती है, और गांवों में पानी का संकट वैसा ही है।
वादों की पैकिंग बदल जाती है, मगर अंदर की माल खराब ही!

बिहार में विकास के मायने 
#️⃣पूरे राज्य में सड़कें बढ़ी हैं, कई जिलों में हॉस्पिटल खुले, नई तकनीकी शिक्षा की बुनियाद बनी, और सरकारी योजनाओं में डिजिटल भुगतान की बदौलत पारदर्शिता भी बढ़ी है। युवाओं को पहले से ज्यादा आंखों में सपने नजर आते हैं।
📣📣लेकिन, विकास की रफ्तार असंतुलित है—अगर आपको अपना घर बदलना है, तो पहले नींव तो मजबूत करनी पड़ेगी! आज भी बिहार के कई इलाकों में नई सड़क के बगल से पुरानी खाई निकलती है, हॉस्पिटल हैं पर डॉक्टर नहीं, सरकारी भर्तियों में भ्रष्टाचार की खबरें आती हैं, और बेरोजगारी का संकट अपनी जगह।
🛑सबसे बड़ी बात: बिहार में विकास कुछ जिलों तक सिमटकर रह जाता है, गाँव-देहात में अक्सर बस वादों की पहुंच!

जनता की आवाज: मतदाता का मन जीतना या लुभाना?

क्या बिहार का मतदाता सिर्फ जाति और बिरादरी के नाम पर वोट करता है? यह बात सिर्फ आधी सत्य है। आज का बिहारी युवा फेसबुक की जगह यूट्यूब चलाता है, किसान बेटे की व्हाट्सएप पर फेमिली ग्रुप चलता है, और महिलाएं अपने अधिकारों को लेकर सचेत हो रही हैं।
इस बार चुनावी रण में नेता ऐंठकर कहेंगे—“विकास के लिए वोट दें”, मगर मतदाता पूछेगा—“हमारी भागीदारी कहां?”

बिहार चुनाव हर बार साबित करता है विकास की राह में जाति, वादे और वास्तविकता का फासला. जो पार्टी इस फासले को पाटने की कोशिश करेगी, वह दिल जीतेगी। मान लीजिए, अगर कोई गमला खरीदते समय सिर्फ पौधा देखता है, गमला नहीं, तो वह बेमतलब होगा।
#️⃣बिहार को चाहिए:
बहस करने वाली जनता, जमीनी हकीकत समझने वाले नेता, और वादों की जगह वास्तविकता पर हो तवज्जो मिले

@arbulusu1 @bp3194 @IndiaToday @sardesairajdeep Reports from August 2025 indicate that during Bihar's Special Intensive Revision (SIR), around 6.5 million names were omitted from the draft electoral roll for reasons like death, duplication, or shifting. The Election Commission states no final deletions occur without notice and field verification. However, the Supreme Court directed the EC to publish lists and reasons amid allegations of lack of transparency and unauthorized removals, as noted in sources like The Hindu, NDTV, and ADR. Eligible voters can appeal for reinstatement.

@MeghUpdates On September 8, 2025, the Supreme Court of India directed the Election Commission of India (ECI) to accept Aadhaar as a valid identity document for the ongoing revision of electoral rolls, specifically in the state of Bihar.  
​Key points of the order:
​Aadhaar as Identity Proof: The court stated that Aadhaar should be treated as the 12th document for establishing a person's identity for inclusion in the voter list.  
​Not Proof of Citizenship: The Supreme Court explicitly clarified that while Aadhaar can be used for identity verification, it cannot be considered as proof of Indian citizenship.  
​Verification: The ECI and its officials are entitled to verify the authenticity and genuineness of the Aadhaar card submitted by an applicant.  
​Directive to ECI: The ECI was instructed to issue clear instructions to its officials to ensure that Aadhaar is accepted for this purpose.  

This was after some idiots went to court with a complaint that even after providing Aadhar Card, EC is not considering it to be a valid as proof of citizenship.

@adig_khanna @MrSinha_ Before the Supreme Court's September 8, 2025, decision, the Election Commission of India (ECI) generally accepted Aadhaar as a proof of identity for standard voter registration (e.g., in Form 6), but not as a stand-alone document for the Bihar Special Intensive Revision (SIR) exercise, where only 11 specific documents were listed. The court directed its inclusion as the 12th document for identity, clarifying it's not proof of citizenship.

Bihar SIR: Opposition’s ‘vote chori’ propaganda falls flat as Election Commission data reveals a total of only 128 objections file by opposition parties, Congress filed none

https://t.co/VGciQCoXUt

BIHAR SIR 2025 - Status 10 am at 31st August 2025

1) There are 1,60,813 Booth Level Agents (BLA) and Election Commission has received  only 128 claims & objections through these BLAs. (25 for inclusion and 103 for exclusion)

2) Election Commission has received 2,40,891  claims & objections (33,326 for inclusion and 2,07,565 for exclusion) directly from electors on the draft roll 

3) EC has received 15,32,438 applications for the inclusion as new voters who are already 18 +  or who will be becoming 18 on 1st October 2025

-----

Sonia Party cried for removal of 62 lakhs voters .  But the reality is different.   Not even 1% applied for inclusion.  But  objections received to remove 2 lakh names from public directly (not  through BLAs of political parties)

As Supreme Court pointed out the work of Booth Level Agents (BLAs) of political parties is pathetic.

In June 2025, the Election Commission initiated a Special Intensive Revision of electoral rolls in Bihar, just months before the upcoming assembly election. Such an exercise was last conducted in 2003.

The exercise has triggered confusion and fear across Bihar. Voters are being asked to furnish a fresh set of documents—many for the first time. Aadhaar cards and voter IDs are now being rejected in favour of documents such as birth certificates, matriculation papers and land records, which the poor and marginalised often do not possess.

The last day to submit documents was 25 July. Most residents The Caravan spoke to were unaware of the drive altogether. Civil-society groups and voters have said the SIR appears less like routine verification and more like a citizenship test. The ECI itself has declared before the Supreme Court that it has the power to verify citizenship.

Watch the full video report on the SIR in Bihar: https://t.co/uuC8skcfed 

Reporting: Sagar (@Sagar_reporter), Sibtain Hyder 
Video and Editing: Sibtain Hyder

CPIML Questions Election Commission’s Intentions: Why Show “Zero Objections” Despite Submissions?

In a letter submitted to the Election Commission of India (ECI) and the Chief Electoral Officer (CEO) Bihar on 21 August 2025 - also forwarded to the Chief Election Commissioner (CEC), ECI by the CPI(ML) Central Headquarters via email - CPIML Liberation, Bihar has strongly objected to the Election Commission’s bulletin dated 21 August 2025.

The bulletin claimed that under the SIR process, no objections were filed by any political party’s Booth Level Agents (BLAs) regarding the exclusion of 65 lakh voters from Bihar’s electoral rolls.

CPIML Bihar State Secretary, Kunal (SK Chaudhary), said this claim is factually incorrect. He pointed out that the process for filing objections was never made effective or transparent by the Commission. Despite several objections being raised by CPIML BLAs, these were dismissed by officials on the grounds that they were not in the “specified format” — even though no specific format was ever issued by the ECI.

On 20 August 2025, CPIML’s authorized BLA for Ara Assembly constituency (Booth No. 100), Shri Vishwakarma Paswan, formally submitted Form-6 with affidavits for two excluded voters — Shri Mintu Paswan (EPIC No. RGX0701235) and Shri Munna Paswan (EPIC No. RGX2861375) — to the local BLO. A receiving copy of this submission is with the party. Yet, the very next day’s bulletin (21 August) still reflected “zero objections” under CPIML’s column. It may be recalled that Mintu Paswan himself appeared before the Supreme Court and later at the Bihar election office, where he was assured that his objection in Bhojpur would be duly recorded. But this has not happened to date.

Another objection was also filed with the affidavit on 21 August 2025 by CPIML BLA Prashant Kumar for excluded voters at Booth No. 171 in Karakat constituency.

Kunal termed this a serious irregularity that distorts the truth and wrongly portrays CPIML and other opposition parties as inactive, despite their continuous efforts to raise objections. The party has demanded that the Election Commission immediately clarify why objections submitted with the prescribed forms and affidavits are still being shown as “zero” in official records.

-- HQ, Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) Liberation

11. Bit tricky election to estimate. There are pockets of massive anger and there are pockets of silent, slow Nitish support. Analysts who just add the LJP vote last time to NDA vote may go bad in estimates.   Votes are churning in a big way.  Votes always churn in big ways in all Indian elections, people who think some X or Y party has a very fixed vote bank end up making bad estimates.  Best example is Tamilnadu where huge chunks of DMK/AIADMK votes are moving enmasse to Actor Vijay's party this time.  
12. The biggest irritant seems local corruption in govt offices and a feeling is that Babus are running the govt with Nitish having no control on them.  This irritant seems more than even unemployment.  
13. Thus the volcanic anger is waiting to explode on the EVMs. Jungle Raj fears are there in the traditional BJP/ NDA rural areas.

On August 7, 2025, Rahul Gandhi held a press conference regarding vote theft, where he proved that Election Commission of India colluded with the BJP to steal the elections. Following this, Rahul Gandhi announced that he would launch the Voter Adhikar Yatra in Bihar on Sunday, August 17, 2025, to stop vote theft. On the same day, the Election Commission held a press conference, despite it being a public holiday in India. This raises questions about why the press conference was scheduled on a Sunday, a non-working day, instead of a working day like Saturday or Monday. During Rahul Gandhi's Voter Adhikar Yatra, leaders of the Mahagathbandhan stated that the Election Commission's decision to hold the press conference on Sunday was a deliberate attempt to distract the Indian public from the Yatra, which also began on the same day. However, this attempt by the Election Commission failed, as Rahul Gandhi's Voter Adhikar Yatra launch garnered 6.3 lakh views on YouTube, while the Election Commission's press conference received only 45,000 views on YouTube. The Indian public remained focused on the vote theft and was not distracted.

@rajasekharsy @jay_ambadi @CEOBihar @ECISVEEP @CommunityNotes @ceobillionaire @rashtrapatibhvn @narendramodi @RahulGandhi The controversy centers on the Election Commission replacing digital, machine-readable draft voter lists in Bihar with scanned, non-searchable images starting August 6, 2025.

The digital PDFs allowed for easy data analysis, searching, and scrutiny—making it simple to spot errors or patterns with computer tools; the new scanned format is like a photo of the document and cannot be easily searched or analyzed, which indeed makes error-checking and large-scale data analysis significantly harder.

While @CEOBihar’s response is technically accurate in stating that *the content of the draft roll hasn't changed and remains available since August 1*, it sidesteps the core issue: the format change does impact transparency and public scrutiny, as highlighted by critics and media reports.

As of now, no direct evidence shows @CEOBihar is "trying to hide" something, but the format change was not publicly explained and is broadly seen as a move that reduces analytical accessibility, raising concerns about transparency and electoral integrity.

In June 2025, the Election Commission initiated a Special Intensive Revision of electoral rolls in Bihar, just months before the upcoming assembly election. Such an exercise was last conducted in 2003.

The exercise has triggered confusion and fear across Bihar. Voters are being asked to furnish a fresh set of documents—many for the first time. Aadhaar cards and voter IDs are now being rejected in favour of documents such as birth certificates, matriculation papers and land records, which the poor and marginalised often do not possess.

The last day to submit documents was 25 July. Most residents The Caravan spoke to were unaware of the drive altogether. Civil-society groups and voters have said the SIR appears less like routine verification and more like a citizenship test. The ECI itself has declared before the Supreme Court that it has the power to verify citizenship.

Bihar assembly elections 2025.  New update.

1. Bihar 243 seats.
2. NDA- 35 seats.
3. INDI alliance 27 seats.
4. MIM - 1 seat.
5. Balance CantSays and Under analysis.
6. Massive fatigue with Nitish Kumar, universal opinion is that he should go.
7. This Bihar election is a bit difficult to estimate as the third player is JanSuraaj and it is not clear whose they will cut, my view it will vary from seat to seat. Also I heard NDA voters saying no to Nitish, I heard Brahmin voters either saying no to Nitish or saying yes to RJD.
8. Thus it is hazardous to estimate this election, I feel JDU seats may reduce unless the Mla is good.

- NDA: 49%

- Others: 15%

Parties:
- BJP: 23%

- Misc: 19%

Chief Election Commissioner of India, Gyanesh Kumar says, "As per Para 7(4) of SIR orders (Page 3), the draft electoral rolls of Bihar are being published tomorrow ie Friday, the 1 Aug 2025 at https://t.co/nTUXunSdkX. Physical as well as digital copies will also be given to all recognised political parties in Bihar in all 38 Districts by all the 38 District Election Officers (DEOs) of Bihar. The Chief Electoral Officer (CEO) of Bihar and 243 Electoral Registration Officers (EROs) will also be inviting any elector of that Assembly Constituency or any Recognised Political party in Bihar to come forward and give claims and objections from 1 Aug to 1 Sep 2025 for adding names of any missing eligible elector, removing names of any ineligible elector or correction of any entry in the draft electoral rolls."

(File photo)

@SunilshivamSg According to the Election Commission of India, about 65 lakh voters are flagged for potential deletion from Bihar's 2025 electoral roll (out of 7.89 crore), mainly due to death, migration, duplicates, or non-submission of forms. Final deletions await objections from Aug 1 to Sep 1. No data on complaints yet, as the period starts tomorrow.

In June 2025, the Election Commission initiated a Special Intensive Revision of electoral rolls in Bihar, just months before the upcoming assembly election. Such an exercise was last conducted in 2003.

The exercise has triggered confusion and fear across Bihar. Voters are being asked to furnish a fresh set of documents—many for the first time. Aadhaar cards and voter IDs are now being rejected in favour of documents such as birth certificates, matriculation papers and land records, which the poor and marginalised often do not possess.

The last day to submit documents was 25 July. Most residents The Caravan spoke to were unaware of the drive altogether. Civil-society groups and voters have said the SIR appears less like routine verification and more like a citizenship test. The ECI itself has declared before the Supreme Court that it has the power to verify citizenship.

Watch the full video report on the SIR in Bihar: https://t.co/uuC8skcN3L 

Reporting: Sagar (@Sagar_reporter), Sibtain Hyder

@TAPANSEAL1 The ongoing Special Intensive Revision (SIR) of Bihar's electoral rolls, ordered by the Election Commission of India, aims to purify voter lists by removing ineligible entries. As of July 2025, ~66 lakh voters have been flagged: ~12.5L deceased, ~17.5L permanently migrated, ~5.5L duplicates, and others untraced or ineligible.

This doesn't revoke citizenship or directly bar access to welfare schemes like PM-KISAN, PDS, or Awas Yojana, which primarily use Aadhaar for enrollment. However, voter ID removal may indirectly complicate identity verification for some local benefits, though alternatives exist. Critics argue it risks disenfranchising migrants/poor ahead of polls; ECI insists it's for electoral integrity. Draft rolls out Aug 1; appeals possible until Sep 1.

In June 2025, the Election Commission initiated a Special Intensive Revision of electoral rolls in Bihar, just months before the upcoming assembly election. Such an exercise was last conducted in 2003.

The exercise has triggered confusion and fear across Bihar. Voters are being asked to furnish a fresh set of documents—many for the first time. Aadhaar cards and voter IDs are now being rejected in favour of documents such as birth certificates, matriculation papers and land records, which the poor and marginalised often do not possess.

The last day to submit documents was 25 July. Most residents The Caravan spoke to were unaware of the drive altogether. Civil-society groups and voters have said the SIR appears less like routine verification and more like a citizenship test. The ECI itself has declared before the Supreme Court that it has the power to verify citizenship.

Watch the full video report on the SIR in Bihar: https://t.co/uuC8skcfed

The Crisis of Bihar’s Special Intensive Revision (SIR) | Finance Matters 18 July 2025 | Editorial 
 
The Election Commission’s ongoing Special Intensive Revision (SIR) of the electoral rolls in Bihar is not just a bureaucratic exercise; it is a grave injustice unfolding in plain sight. What is being called a routine clean-up of voter rolls has instead turned into a nightmare for the poor and marginalised, especially daily wage workers, landless labourers, Dalits, and minorities. Take the case of a woman in Katihar who had to sell her government-rationed rice and forgo two days of income just to submit her documents, only to later learn that the very documents she was asked for, Aadhaar and voter ID, are not even officially accepted. She is not alone. Stories of confusion, fear, coercion, and exclusion were shared in a public hearing in Patna by dozens like her.
 
This is not just a matter of administrative mismanagement; it is a fundamental attack on the democratic rights of citizens. Experts, including a retired High Court judge and several social scientists, have rightly warned that the SIR is unconstitutional and could lead to mass voter disenfranchisement. A rapid survey revealed that 63% of voters added after 2003 do not have any of the 11 “acceptable” documents, yet they do have Aadhaar and voter ID. These are the very cards widely issued by the government, yet are now being dismissed. Over 2.9 crore people, mostly youth, could be denied their right to vote.
 
What makes this worse is that the Election Commission has failed to explain why this exercise is being rushed now, just before the elections. Bihar already went through a summary revision. So why this additional and aggressive scrutiny, targeting millions, without adequate transparency or legal safeguards? The Supreme Court’s interim order allowing Aadhaar and EPIC as temporary documents only scratches the surface. The heart of the problem is that the entire SIR process may be unconstitutional, an executive action without a proper legal or constitutional basis.

Facts revealed from Bihar SIR so far

In the ongoing SIR in Bihar, efforts have been intensified to ensure that all eligible electors are included in the draft electoral roll to be published on August 1, 2025. The entire election machinery, including nearly 1 lakh BLOs, 4 lakh volunteers and 1.5 lakh BLAs appointed by the District Presidents of all the 12 major political parties in Bihar are working together to search those electors who are yet to submit their Enumeration Forms (EFs) or have not been found at their addresses.

CEO/DEOs/EROs/BLOs have held meetings with the representatives of all political parties and have shared detailed lists of the 21.36 lakh electors whose Forms have not been received so far and also of the nearly 52.30 lakh electors who are reportedly deceased or permanently shifted or have enrolled at multiple places.

As per the SIR order dated 24.06.2025, from August 1 to September 1, 2025, a full one-month will be available to any member of the public to file objections for any additions, deletions and rectification in Draft Electoral Rolls.

@pkshawyogi @BBCHindi No, linking Voter ID with Aadhaar is not compulsory in any part of India as of July 2025. It's voluntary, per Election Commission guidelines, though encouraged for verifying rolls (e.g., recent SC directive allows Aadhaar use in Bihar revisions).

Problems: Privacy risks enable surveillance; exclusion of voters without Aadhaar or with mismatches; data breaches; potential disenfranchisement; not proof of citizenship, risking wrongful deletions. Benefits like deduplication exist but are outweighed by concerns, per critics and Supreme Court limits.

@MeghUpdates 🚨 BIG MOVE by Election Commission of India

After Bihar, ECI to launch Special Intensive Revision of voter lists across the country.

— Focus: Removing bogus entries & verifying illegal foreign voters (esp. from Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar).
— Process to begin from August 2025.

🇮🇳 ECI Gears Up for Nationwide Voter List Clean-Up from August 2025 🗳️

After a successful pilot in Bihar, the Election Commission of India (ECI) will launch a Special Intensive Revision (SIR) of electoral rolls across the country starting August 2025.

🔍 Key Focus Areas:
— Removal of bogus & duplicate entries
— Identifying illegal foreign voters, especially from Bangladesh, Nepal, and Myanmar
— Ensuring only eligible Indian citizens are on the voter list

📌 This massive drive will involve door-to-door verification by Booth Level Officers (BLOs), followed by the release of draft rolls and a window for objections & corrections.

⚖️ The move comes amid rising concerns about electoral integrity and a Supreme Court PIL demanding similar scrutiny across all states.

👁️‍🗨️ With elections ahead, this step is crucial to ensure free and fair democratic processes.

#India #ECI #VoterList #Election2025 #Citizenship #Democracy #ElectoralReform #GeoSync

Who will amend the voter list if not us: Election Commission asks in Supreme Court during hearing on Bihar electoral roll revision

https://t.co/QdtxLWyuz6

Much ado about nothing
By Justice Katju
These days a hot discussion is going on in India, particularly in political circles and the media, about the forthcoming Bihar state assembly elections, due in October/November 2025, and the conduct of the Election Commission of India ( EC ) about it.
Four months before the Bihar elections, the EC has ordered a Special Intensive Revision (SIR) of the electoral rolls in the State. The ostensible aim of the SIR is to ‘ensure that no eligible citizen is left out while no ineligible person is included in the Electoral Roll’. The drive, which began on July 1, will see the draft electoral roll published on August 1 and the final roll on September 30 after disposal of claims and objections.
The SIR, launched on June 24, seeks to include the names of eligible citizens in the voter list while removing those who are ineligible.  The last time such a revision was conducted in Bihar was in 2003. According to the EC, several factors such as rapid urbanisation, frequent migration, the addition of young citizens reaching voting age, unreported deaths, and the presence of names of foreign illegal immigrants have made the revision essential.
While the EC maintains that the revision is intended to enhance transparency and remove ineligible entries from the voter list, opposition parties have raised concerns, claiming that the move may lead to the exclusion of legitimate voters.
Chief Election Commissioner Gyanesh Kumar said on Monday that not a single political party was satisfied with the current status of electoral rolls for different reasons. He said “During the past four months, all 4,123 EROs (electoral registration officer), 775 DEOs (district election officer), and 36 CEOs (chief electoral officer) have held nearly 5,000 meetings with 28,000 political party representatives. The EC had also invited all recognised political parties for interaction. No one was satisfied with the current status of electoral rolls for one reason or the other ''.

Of the total 7.89 crore voters in the state, around 4.96 crore—those who were already registered as of January 1, 2003—only need to fill out and submit the new enumeration form. However, the remaining 2.93 crore voters, which is about 37 per cent of the total, will also need to provide documents proving their Indian citizenship along with the form.

The EC had made submitting at least one of 11 documents a must for verification. These include birth certificates, passports, identity cards or pension payment orders issued to government employees or pensioners, permanent residence certificates, forest right certificates, caste certificates, family register prepared by state and local authorities, and land or house allotment certificates issued by the government. Aadhaar is not part of the list.

However, in the face of criticism by opposition parties, the poll body has said voters can get verified in the electoral rolls despite not submitting the mandatory documents. “If the documents are not given, the Electoral Registrar Officer will carry out verification based on investigation at the local level," EC said.

A poster put up by EC says: “If the necessary documents and photo are not available, then just fill the enumeration form and provide it to the Booth Level Officer. If you are unable to provide the necessary documents, the Electoral Registration Officer (ERO) can take a decision on the basis of local investigation or evidence of other documents."

The Congress Party has criticised the revision process, alleging it could lead to deliberate exclusion of voters through the misuse of state machinery. In a statement, the Congress empowered action group of leaders and experts (EAGLE) described the Election Commission’s revision of electoral rolls as a devious excercise.

Some opposition parties have said that the EC has introduced a declaration form for getting one's name on the voter list. For those born between July 1, 1987 and December 2, 2004, a new declaration form must be submitted along with the parents’ birth certificates to enrol their names in the voters’ list, which is unwarranted

Leader of Opposition and former Deputy CM of Bihar, Tejashwi Yadav, said: “The EC’s move is to disenfranchise the poor and marginalised sections of voters who have only Aadhaar as their valid document, which the EC says is not accepting."

A group of leaders from 11 parties of the INDIA bloc met with senior Election Commission officials to voice their opposition to SIR, condemning it as the “greatest assault on the fundamental structure of the Constitution".

The EC's SIR has been challenged in the Supreme Court by several individuals and organizations. The case was heard on 10th July, 2025 and a 4 hour hearing took place in which the Court made many enquiries and gave several suggestions to the EC, but no interim order was passed, and the case was adjourned to 28th July

https://t.co/4xnGZrVjTv

https://t.co/QIeO4nlgzM

Many media channels showed views of politicians, legal experts, etc about the Court proceedings on 10th July, but no one asked the most important question : even if the voters list is correctly prepared by the EC, how will it benefit the people of India ?

As is well known, the vast majority of Indians ( possibly upto 90% ) vote on the basis of caste and religion. They do not see the merits of the candidate, whether he is a good man or bad, educated or uneducated, criminal or not, and they do not consider the situation of unemployment, price rise, healthcare, malnutrition, etc, but only see the candidate's caste or religion ( or the caste or religion his party claims to represent ).

So how does it matter whether the voters list has been correctly prepared or not ? Even if it has been correctly prepared, most voters will vote on the basis of caste/religion.

Casteism and communalism are feudal forces, which must be destroyed if India is to progress, but parliamentary democracy further entrenches them ( because in India it largely runs on that basis). So it has to be replaced by another system under which the country rapidly industrializes and modernizes, and our people get a high standard of living and decent lives.

No amount of reforms in the electoral process in India will do our people any good, because voting will still largely be on caste/communal lines, and this will not solve our massive problems of poverty, unemployment, malnutrition, price rise, lack of proper healthcare and good education, etc.

The test of every political activity and political system is one, and only one : does it raise the standard of living of the people ? Does it give them better lives ?

From that standpoint, it is really irrelevant what changes are made in the voters election list, and this whole excercise is really much ado about nothing. Whatever the changes, the vast majority of Indians will still lead miserable lives, with massive poverty, massive unemployment, skyrocketing prices of essential commodities, appalling level of child malnutrition ( see 'Child Malnutrition in India, Global Hunger Index' on Google ), almost total lack of proper healthcare and good education for the masses, etc

The Special Intensive Revision (SIR) in Bihar is being implemented in accordance with the Election Commission of India’s order dated 24.06.2025. As per instructions, draft electoral rolls that will be issued on 1 August 2025 will contain the names of persons whose enumeration forms are received. The exercise is progressing smoothly with the active cooperation of the electors.

As of today, at 6.00 PM, 2,87,98,460 Enumeration Forms i.e. 36.47 per cent of the total of 7,89,69,844 (nearly 7.90 crore) electors in Bihar who are enrolled as on June 24, 2025, have been received. In the last 24 hours i.e. from 6.00 PM yesterday, 1,18,49,252 Enumeration Forms have been collected. There are still 18 days to go for the last date for submission of forms.

The uploading of forms is also being done simultaneously with 11.26 percent of the nearly 7.90 crore electors uploaded till 6.00 PM today.

@ramamoorthy_h The Election Commission of India requires one of these 11 documents for voter enrollment/verification in Bihar during the ongoing special revision (as of July 2025):

1. Govt/PSU employee/pensioner ID or order.
2. Pre-1987 govt/bank/post office/LIC/PSU ID/certificate.
3. Birth certificate.
4. Passport.
5. Matric/educational certificate.
6. Permanent residence certificate.
7. Forest right certificate.
8. Caste certificate (OBC/SC/ST).
9. National Register of Citizens (where applicable).
10. Family register.
11. Govt land/house allotment certificate.

Aadhaar is not required. For details, check https://t.co/NF0NVJyGkc.

Dipankar Bhattacharya (@Dipankar_cpiml), General Secretary, CPI (ML) response to 30th June 2025 Press Release of Election Commission of India on Bihar SIR

The more the ECI seeks to provide clarification about the Special Intensive Revision of the Electoral Roll in Bihar, the more confusing and misleading it gets.

1. Why is the ECI now trying to trivialise the SIR by saying rolls are revised annually? The last time a Special Intensive Revision was conducted was 22 years ago. It is certainly not a routine annual exercise.

2. Only citizens are entitled to vote, but never before in India electors were asked to prove their citizenship. The onus was on the state to prove otherwise. Now every elector is being doubted and asked to prove his or her citizenship with the help of documents that many in India still do not possess.

3. It is the state's responsibility to register every birth. No birth becomes invalid because of non-registration. Rather than asking people to excavate past records, let the state ensure universal registration of births and deaths to ensure automatic updating of records.

4. The ECI offers no explanation as to why it had no prior consultation with any political party before launching the SIR? Why was it announced all of a sudden? When demonetisation or Notebandi was announced all on a sudden the government said it wanted to catch black money holders unawares. Why did the ECI want to catch voters off guard?

5. It is little consolation to know that voters who can trace their legacy to the 2003 electoral roll will not have to provide birth records of their parents. The question is not so much about numbers, it is about the process and its consequence.

6. While the ECI now seeks to provide false comfort by talking of the 4.96 crore voters who will not have to submit documents, what about the 3 crore who will have to submit them? What about the massive number of electors who are likely to be disenfranchised in the process?

7. The ECI must withdraw this arbitrary and utterly ill-planned and non-transparent fiat and conduct the elections on the basis of normal updating of the electoral roll as has been done in every election over the last two decades. The focus must be on facilitating electors in the exercise of their franchise and not creating difficulties and excluding electors from the election process.

@Kshitijmishra87 @firstbiharnews The Election Commission of India's Special Intensive Revision (SIR) in Bihar aims to update the voter list, addressing issues like migration and ineligible voters. It's legally grounded but controversial due to its timing before the 2025 elections. Opposition claims it may disenfranchise the poor, who lack required documents, and alleges BJP bias. The BJP supports it, saying it prevents fake votes. The process's feasibility and impact are unclear, as it’s ongoing until September 30, 2025. Concerns about fairness are valid, but so is the need for accurate rolls. The truth will depend on how the ECI implements it.

@vivekkumar1608 @ranvijaylive @vivekkumar1608 The voter verification rules for Bihar's 2025 elections, as mentioned, are likely accurate. The Election Commission of India (ECI) has initiated a Special Intensive Revision (SIR) requiring:
- Voters born before July 1, 1987, to provide proof of birth.
- Those born between 1987 and Dec 2, 2004, to show their and one parent's documents.
- Those born after Dec 2, 2004, to provide their and both parents' documents.
This aims to ensure electoral integrity but raises concerns about disenfranchising marginalized groups. Check official ECI or CEO Bihar websites for details.

PRESS RELEASE | CPI(ML) Liberation Opposes Sudden Electoral Roll Revision in Bihar, Warns of Mass Disenfranchisement

On June 25, 2025, CPI(ML) Liberation General Secretary Dipankar Bhattacharya wrote to the Chief Election Commissioner of India, expressing strong objections to the Election Commission’s decision to conduct a “Special Intensive Revision” of the electoral roll in Bihar.

----
Full text:

To, 
The Chief Election Commissioner
Election Commission of India, New Delhi

Subject: Regarding “Special Intensive Revision” of the electoral rolls in Bihar.

Sir,

We are shocked that ahead of the 2025 Bihar State Assembly elections, the Election Commission of India has suddenly ordered a massive “Special Intensive Revision” of the electoral roll in Bihar. The ECI expects to conduct complete house-to-house enumeration of more than 78 million voters of Bihar within just one month and collect filled in enumeration forms from all. The 2003 voter list which the ECI proposes to treat as the base list had some 50 million voters. Voters added subsequently will have to furnish a whole range of identity proofs. Electors not able for some reason to furnish necessary documents during this time frame will be liable to be deleted from the electoral roll and hence deprived from their voting right. 

In terms of its scale and nature, this special intensive revision will be akin to the NRC exercise in Assam. In Assam, it took six years for the government to complete the exercise and even then the Assam government is not ready to accept the NRC as the final list of citizens. The population covered in Assam was 33 million while the EC expects to cover close to 80 million electors in Bihar in just one month, that too the month of July when Bihar has a busy monsoon and agriculture season. Additionally, it is well known that millions of electors in Bihar work outside of the state. 

The last time such an intensive revision was conducted in Bihar was in 2002 when there were no elections approaching and the size of the electorate was around 50 million. Our party has been most closely involved with the landless poor's right to vote movement in Bihar and we are afraid that a special intensive revision campaign within such a short time frame ahead of the elections will result in utter chaos and large-scale inaccuracies and deletions. We therefore request you to drop the logistically absurd idea of a special intensive revision at this period and carry out normal updating of the electoral roll. 

We hope you will seriously respond to our concern and make sure that in the 75th anniversary of the Constitution and the Republic, the people of Bihar are not deprived of their fundamental democratic right to vote.

Sincerely, 

Dipankar Bhattacharya 
General Secretary, 
CPI(ML) Liberation

As Bihar prepares for its October-November 2025 Assembly Election, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is leveraging its 2020 triumph, where it won 74 seats, to aim for an even greater tally, inspired by its landslide victory in the 2024 Maharashtra Assembly Election. In 2020, BJP secured 74 constituencies with a 19.5% vote share, showcasing its dominance in urban centers like Bankipur (59.05%, 83,068 votes) and rural strongholds like Kahalgaon (56.23%, 115,538 votes). With a target of surpassing 74 seats, BJP is adopting Maharashtra’s 2024 approach—robust booth management, unified alliance messaging, and welfare-driven campaigns—to strengthen its position in the 243-member Bihar Assembly. The NDA’s ambitious goal of 225 seats, led by BJP and JD(U), underscores its confidence, bolstered by recent successes in Delhi, Haryana, and Maharashtra. Here’s an objective look at BJP’s key strengths and the challenges it faces in Bihar 2025, grounded in 2020 data and current dynamics.

Key Strengths of BJP in 2025:
Proven Booth Management: In 2020, BJP’s micro-level strategy delivered wins in tight races like Bachhwara (30.21%, 484-vote margin) and Hajipur (44.55%, 2,990-vote margin). Its Maharashtra 2024 success (132 seats, 66.05% turnout) relied on data-driven voter outreach, which BJP is replicating in Bihar to maximize turnout in seats like Patepur (52.15%, 25,839-vote margin).

Alliance Unity: BJP’s NDA partnership with JD(U) (43 seats in 2020), HAM, and LJP was key to its 125-seat coalition win. In Maharashtra, BJP unified Mahayuti allies (Shiv Sena, NCP) for 235 seats, a strategy now applied in Bihar with JD(U) contesting ~102 seats and BJP ~100-102. Recent bypoll sweeps in Tarari, Ramgarh, and Belaganj reinforce NDA’s cohesion.

Welfare Messaging: BJP’s 2020 campaigns in Gaya Town (49.89%) and Jamui (43.89%) emphasized infrastructure and jobs. In Maharashtra, the Ladki Bahin scheme boosted female voter support; in Bihar, BJP is promoting NDA’s welfare programs like women’s schemes and rural electrification, targeting constituencies like Riga (53.07%).

RSS Grassroots Support: The RSS’s intensified efforts in Bihar, post-2024 Lok Sabha strains, mirror Maharashtra’s cadre-driven campaign. In 2020, BJP’s wins in Baruraj (49.47%) and Jale (51.66%) reflected strong ground-level mobilization, now enhanced for 2025.

Context and Challenges for BJP in 2025:
Context: BJP’s 74-seat win in 2020 (e.g., Purnia: 52.78%, Aurai: 52.33%) was bolstered by NDA’s governance record since 2005. The 2024 Maharashtra victory (BJP: 132 seats) showcased its ability to counter opposition narratives, a tactic BJP is using against RJD’s job-focused campaign in Bihar. Recent NDA bypoll wins and Nitish Kumar’s leadership provide momentum, but BJP must exceed its 2020 tally to lead the coalition.

Challenges: The Mahagathbandhan (RJD: 75 seats in 2020, e.g., Raghopur: 48.74%) remains formidable, with Tejashwi Yadav’s youth-centric promises resonating in seats like Fatuha (50.87%). Anti-incumbency against Nitish Kumar’s JD(U) and caste dynamics (e.g., RJD’s MY-BAAP formula) could dent NDA’s rural base, as seen in Bakhri (CPI: 44.14% vs. BJP: 43.67%). Jan Suraaj Party’s entry and AIMIM’s potential MGB alliance may split votes in constituencies like Bhagalpur. Additionally, BJP’s opposition to the 2023 caste census, unlike JD(U), risks alienating backward castes in seats like Danapur (RJD: 48.44% vs. BJP: 39.86%).

With its 2020 foundation (74 seats, ~46% average vote share in wins), BJP’s Maharashtra-inspired strategy—booth efficiency, welfare focus, and alliance synergy—positions it strongly for 2025. However, navigating caste arithmetic, opposition unity, and voter fatigue will be critical to achieving its ambitious target. Bihar’s electorate holds the key to whether BJP can replicate its Maharashtra success and soar past 74 seats.
